section_01.section_summary: Jean Honoré Fragonard was born on April 5, 1732, in the town of Grasse, France, to a glovemaker and his wife. Growing up in a picturesque region surrounded by olive trees and Mediterranean waters, Fragonard was inspired by the beauty of his surroundings, which would later influence his art. As he grew older, he became aware of the gossip and scandals of the French court, including the rise of Madame de Pompadour, who became a powerful patron of the arts. Despite his father's initial plans for him to become a notary, Fragonard's passion for art led him to pursue a different path, with his master eventually advising that he be allowed to follow his artistic bent. Fragonard's early life in Grasse and his exposure to the artistic movements of the time, including the work of François Boucher, laid the foundation for his future as a renowned artist.

section_02.section_summary: In 1749, a 16-year-old Jean-Honoré Fragonard traveled to Paris with his mother to pursue a career in art, seeking out the renowned painter François Boucher. Boucher, impressed by Fragonard's potential, advised him to train with Jean-Siméon Chardin to develop his skills, but Fragonard was eventually dismissed from Chardin's studio due to lack of progress. Undeterred, Fragonard continued to hone his craft, and after six months, he returned to Boucher, who was astonished by his improvement and took him on as a student. Fragonard went on to win the Prix de Rome at the age of 20 and later traveled to Italy, where he was influenced by the works of Tiepolo and developed his unique style. During his time in Italy, Fragonard formed lasting friendships with fellow artists Hubert Robert and the Abbé de Saint-Non, which helped to establish his reputation as a talented young artist.

section_03.section_summary: After spending five years in Italy, Fragonard returned to Paris in 1761, where he found that his master Boucher was struggling with the changing public taste and criticism from the new philosophers. Fragonard initially attempted to paint in the academic style, but soon turned to painting the life and beauty around him, which brought him fame and success. His breakthrough came with the painting "Les hazards heureux de l'Escarpolette," which showcased his skill in capturing the beauty of nature and launched him into the spotlight. As the favorite painter of the French court, Fragonard became known for his decorative and lively paintings, often using gallant subjects as an excuse to paint glorious landscapes. He went on to produce numerous works, including "La Fête de St. Cloud" and other notable pieces, cementing his reputation as one of the great landscape-painters of France.

section_04.section_summary: Fragonard's master, Boucher, introduced him to the wealthy and art-loving farmer-general Bergeret de Grandcour, who became one of Fragonard's most important patrons. During this time, Fragonard created several masterpieces, including the "Fête de St. Cloud," and began working on a series of panels for the notorious dancer Mademoiselle Guimard. The Pompadour, a powerful and influential woman, died in 1764, but not before promoting the arts and encouraging artists to paint their own age rather than imitating the past. After her death, Fragonard continued to work on various projects, including portraits of Guimard, and also helped launch the career of the young artist David. Meanwhile, the French court was undergoing significant changes, including the rise of the new mistress, Madame du Barry, who would eventually lead to the downfall of the king's minister, Choiseul.

section_05.section_summary: King Louis XV's infatuation with the Du Barry, a woman of low social status, led to the degradation of the French throne and ultimately cost France dearly. The Du Barry commissioned Fragonard to paint a series of canvases, "The Progress of Love in the Heart of Maidenhood," but she rejected them, possibly due to their lack of indecency. Fragonard's art took a new direction after his marriage to Marie Anne Gérard, as he began to focus on depicting domestic life and rural scenes with beauty and dignity. His marriage and family influenced his art, and he was inspired by the Dutch landscapists, incorporating elements of their style into his work. Fragonard's artistic genius continued to shine, and he proved himself to be an artist incapable of mediocrity, bringing distinction and style to all his works.

section_06.section_summary: The old painter Fragonard was found dead at his easel, marking the end of an era. Meanwhile, the French monarchy was in turmoil, with King Louis XV's mistress, Du Barry, playing a significant role in his downfall, and his eventual death from smallpox in 1774. The new king, Louis XVI, and his queen, Marie Antoinette, took the throne, but the privileged class's scandalous behavior and ruthless vindictiveness had already set France on a path towards revolution. The writings of intellectuals such as Voltaire and Rousseau further fueled the people's discontent, spreading ideas of liberty and freedom. Fragonard, oblivious to the impending doom, embarked on a grand tour of Italy with his patron, Bergeret de Grandcour, enjoying the luxuries of wealth and success.

section_07.section_summary: Fragonard traveled to Italy with Bergeret de Grandcour, where they attended a concert and visited Naples, but their friendship was later marred by a lawsuit over Fragonard's sketches. Upon their return to Paris, Fragonard was granted a studio and apartments at the Louvre, where he lived a comfortable life with his family and sister-in-law, Marguerite Gérard. However, his life was soon disrupted by the French Revolution, which began in 1789 with the fall of the Bastille and the establishment of the National Assembly. As the Revolution gained momentum, Fragonard, who sympathized with the people's suffering, found himself caught up in the turmoil, and his life was forever changed. The Revolution ultimately led to the downfall of the monarchy and the rise of the National Convention, which abolished royalty and established a new republic.

section_08.section_summary: The French Revolution led to a power struggle between the Girondists and Jacobins, resulting in the Reign of Terror, during which thousands of people, including King Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, were executed by guillotine. Fragonard, a renowned artist, was affected by the Revolution, which led to the destruction of his livelihood and the loss of his patrons. He fled to Grasse to escape the turmoil, where he continued to paint, but his style was no longer in fashion. After Napoleon came to power, Fragonard returned to Paris, but his artistic career had declined, and he struggled to adapt to the new artistic trends. The Revolution had brought an end to the elegance and charm of the old regime, replacing it with a severe and frigid morality that stifled Fragonard's artistic expression.

section_09.section_summary: The old painter Fragonard is described as a cheerful and alert man, despite his advanced age, with a distinctive appearance and a love for his work. He lived through significant events, including Napoleon's rise to power and the suppression of the artists' lodging at the Louvre, which led to his relocation. Fragonard's life came to an end on August 22, 1806, when he died at the age of 74, marking the passing of an era for French art. His legacy, along with that of Watteau and Boucher, embodies the spirit of 18th-century France, capturing its elegance, gaiety, and romance. Fragonard's art is considered the last word of a bygone era, one that was marked by excess and pretence, but ultimately gave rise to a new and more authentic France.
